ENGLISH: Vargas was born in the state of Rio Grande do Sul, into a family prominent in state politics. By 1922 he had risen rapidly in state politics and was elected to the National Congress, in which he served for four years. In 1926 Vargas became minister of finance in the Cabinet of President Washington Luís Pereira de Sousa, a post he retained until his election as governor of Rio Grande do Sul in 1928. From his position as state governor, Vargas campaigned unsuccessfully as reform candidate for the presidency of Brazil in 1930. While appearing to accept defeat, Vargas in October of that year led the revolution, organized by his friends, that overthrew the oligarchical republic. For the next 15 years Vargas assumed largely dictatorial powers, ruling most of that time without a congress. He held sole power as provisional president from Nov. 3, 1930, until July 17, 1934, when he was elected president by the constituent assembly.
The Rise of Getulio Vargas
Today you are with the government. Tomorrow you will be the government.
The coffee policy will prevail! Suppress this outrageous coup!

The village of Paraibuna emerged in the early nineteenth century due to the occupation of the region by families of farmers and settlers coming of the former gold producing region (Ouro Preto and Mariana). The county of Paraibuna was separated from Barbacena on May 31, 1850, and was elevated to Paraibuna City in 1856, surpassing the city of São João del Rey. In 1865 the city of Paraibuna was renamed Juiz de Fora.
A City Flourishes
May the city forever flourish.

García Moreno's death in 1875, as he himself might have forecast, brought a period of near anarchy. Conservatives and liberals struggled for power. But Ecuador had become part of the world market: the importance of the coast slowly increased, and the liberals of that area increasingly dominated the economy. A new liberal hero emerged from the lower classes as the leader of the coastal reaction to Sierra conservatism and clericalism. A man of great personal magnetism, Gen. Eloy Alfaro led a march against the Sierra in $YEAR$ and after a year...
The Shift to Liberalism!
...became constitutional president, serving two terms.
...was defeated by reactionaries, Ecuador remained a Dictatorship.

Solano López died in combat. Paraguay lay ruins, with more than half of its former population dead. This brought the end of the War of the Triple Alliance in $YEAR$ and under a liberal constitution promulgated in $YEAR$, Paraguay began a painful reconstruction. The constitution...
The Liberal Constitution
...installed a democracy in a war-torn Paraguay.
...was dissolved, Paraguay remains a Dictatorship!

After the War of the Pacific, a vigorous debate among civilian elites spawned the development of new political parties. Mining entrepreneurs, who had become the most important economic group in the country, created the Conservative Party. Conservatives favoured reaching a quick peace settlement with Chile that would include indemnification for lost territories and enable Bolivia to construct a railroad for mining exports. The Liberal Party denounced the pacifism of the Conservatives. Despite these differences, both parties were primarily interested in political and economic modernization, and their ideological outlooks were similar. The governments in power elected by a small, literate electorate brought Bolivia its first relative political stability and prosperity.
The Democratic Stability
¡Viva la democracia!
No! Bolivia will continue as a Dictatorship.

In $YEAR$, Nicolás de Piérola, after allying his party with the Civil Party of Peru to organize guerrillas with fighters to occupy Lima, ousted Andrés Avelino Cáceres and once again became president of Peru. After a brief period in which the military once again controlled the country, civilian rule was permanently established with Pierola's election. His second term was marked by his reconstruction of a devastated Peru by initiating fiscal, military, religious, and civil reforms. Until the 1920s, this period was called the "Aristocratic Republic", since most of the presidents that ruled the country were from the social elite.
The Aristocratic Republic
¡Viva la democracia!
No! Peru will continue as a Dictatorship.

The course of Venezuelan history changed markedly at the turn of the 20th century. In 1899 General Cipriano Castro, a caudillo from the Andean state of Táchira, descended on Caracas with his provincial army and seized the presidency. As a result, five successive military strongmen from Táchira, known as Andinos, controlled the nation for the next 59 years, except for an interlude in 1945-48. The longest rule being the one of General Juan Vicente Gómez. Gómez was an effective, if ruthless, dictator. By manipulating elections, abolishing all organized political activity, and monopolizing appointive powers, he established a completely subservient legislative and judicial structure.
The Rise of the Andinos
We can’t resist the powerful caudillos.
The Federation must resist this coup!

William Lindsay Scruggs was the US ambassador to both Colombia and Venezuela, and has always been on good terms with our government and an advocate for good relations between our countries. With some persuasion, we can probably get him to lobby for our cause in Washington, pointing out the hypocrisy in not supporting our claims against that of an European colonial power.
A diplomatic opportunity?
Let him go and shame Uncle Sam into action!
Let us not tempt fate with such a brash callout.

In $YEAR$ Scruggs was recruited by the $FROMCOUNTRY_ADJ$ Government to operate on its behalf in Washington D.C. as a lobbyist and legal attache. As a lobbyist, Scruggs published the pamphlet entitled 'British Aggressions in $FROMCOUNTRY$: The Monroe Doctrine on Trial'. In the pamphlet, he attacked "British aggression" claiming that $FROMCOUNTRY$ was anxious to arbitrate over the $FROMCOUNTRY$/British Guiana border dispute of territory at west of Essequibo river limited by Schomburgk Line. Scruggs also claimed that British policies in the disputed territory violated the Monroe Doctrine of 1823. \n \nSuch a public callout of our inaction will be a disaster to our influence in the region if not contained. We must defend the Monroe doctrine, but we should also be cautious of our relations with the other great powers.
Scruggs lobbies for $FROMCOUNTRY_ADJ$ claims
No colonies under our watch!
Demand they yield the left bank of the Essequibo
We should form a committee to decide the demarcation
We mustn't anger the British

The border between the formerly Spanish territories in Guyana has never been solidly determined - while the Schombugk line marked out the material state of affairs, both sides have had extended claims, and an informal dispute has existed since the 1840s. \nRecently the Venezuelans have lobbied in Washington for the Americans to back them under the Monroe doctrine, and they now demand that we leave Guyana altogether. While they did not rattle their sabres in public just yet, the threat of war was very clearly implied.
The Venezuelan border crisis
We will not yield to these idle threats! Britannia rules the waves!
We aren't in a position to defend Guyana now

The British have defied our demands and have begun shoring up defences in Guyana. This is a clear defiance of the Monroe doctrine, of our sphere of influence, and of our status as a great power, in a crisis that is becoming more and more public in the rest of the world. If we don't follow up on our word now, we'll look like fools.
The Venezuelan border crisis
Mine eyes have seen the glory of the coming of the Lord...
On second thought...
Under pressure from the United States, the British have agreed to secede to us the entire left bank of the Essequibo. Finally, our eastern border is complete!
Our territories returned!
Splendid!

The border between the formerly Spanish territories in Guyana has never been solidly determined - while the Schombugk line marked out the material state of affairs, both sides have had extended claims, and an informal dispute has existed since the 1840s. \nRecently the Venezuelans have lobbied in Washington for the Americans to back them under the Monroe doctrine, and they now demand that we respect Venezuelan sovereignty over the entire left bank of the Essequibo. While they did not rattle their sabres in public just yet, the threat of war was very clearly implied.
The Venezuelan border crisis
We will not yield to these idle threats! Britannia rules the waves!
We can offer to sell the territory and demand equity for our losses
We aren't in a position to defend Guyana now

The British have defied our demands and have begun shoring up defences in Guyana. This is a clear defiance of the Monroe doctrine, of our sphere of influence, and of our status as a great power, in a crisis that is becoming more and more public in the rest of the world. If we don't follow up on our word now, we'll look like fools.
The Venezuelan border crisis
Mine eyes have seen the glory of the coming of the Lord...
Cooler heads may yet prevail
On second thought...

The British are offering to sell their holdings on the left bank of the Essequibo if they would be reimbursed for their future losses. While this may make them appear the reasonable party to the outside world, it is clear that they are just looking for reasons to use to dispute the sale later on. It also might not be seen as a popular move to invest so heavily for what many perceive as a worthless strip of land a continent away, for a nation that neither could nor would do the same for us.
The British offer to sell the territory
They insult us! Powder and steel will determine our domain, not gold.
It would be foolhardy to think maintaining our domain would not require investment
Our people would string us up for this - the deal is off

The border between the formerly Spanish territories in Guyana has never been solidly determined - while the Schombugk line marked out the material state of affairs, both sides have had extended claims, and an informal dispute has existed since the 1840s. 
Recently the Venezuelans have lobbied in Washington for the Americans to back them under the Monroe doctrine, and they are insisting that a committee be formed with two American representatives, two British, and one neutral. 
 
Unbeknownst to them, however, the neutral jurist, Friedrich Martens, may be sympathetic to our cause. If we can gain his favour, we can trap the Americans, offering them a saving grace of a unanimous decision in our favour, or a contested 3-2 decision that still favours us, with greater territorial claims. We are confident they will see reason and side with us, but it may be disastrous for our diplomatic image if the plot is found out.
The Venezuelan border arbitration
We will accept a fair decision
Britain has not become what it is today without a bit of subterfuge

The United States have withdrawn their support from our cause and yielded to the threats of European imperialist powers in a blatant disregard for the Monroe doctrine. While our borders, and our claims, do not change for the time being, it might be time for the people of $COUNTRY$, and maybe all of South America, to look elsewhere for protection.
The Americans abandon us!
Damnation!
Winds of change blow in $CAPITAL$

The arbitration committee for the border between our holdings in Guyana and Venezuela had, to the shock of many, found against us. Britain's key argument was that prior to Venezuela's independence, Spain had not taken effective possession of the disputed territory and said that the local Indians had had alliances with the Dutch, which gave them a sphere of influence that the British acquired in 1814. The American arbitrators found the British argument preposterous since American Indians had never been considered to have any sovereignty.\n \nWhile it may be extremely unpopular with the international community, we can just ignore the committee's decision and call the Americans' bluff on whether they would actually go to war over this.
The Guyana border arbitration
We will concede.
Who is Grover Cleveland to order the British Empire around?

The arbitration committee for the border between our holdings in Guyana and Venezuela had, nobody's surprise, in found in our favour. Britain's key argument was that prior to Venezuela's independence, Spain had not taken effective possession of the disputed territory and said that the local Indians had had alliances with the Dutch, which gave them a sphere of influence that the British acquired in 1814. They also argued that Britain would be liable to argue loss of equity for a number of gold mines. In the end, the neutral jurist insisted on a unanimous decision, and the Americans were persuaded to see our way.
The Guyana border arbitration
Splendid!

Information has reached $CAPITAL$ from a confidential source that the British jurists in the committee for arbitration of the Venezuela-Guyana border have attempted to make a deal with the American jurists in order to ensure that the committee finds in Britain's favour. While they were, obviously, not successful in this endeavour, neither side is likely to accept any decision the committee finds, so it is effectively dissolved. This preposterous meddling is unbecoming of a great power, but grumble as we may, there is little that we can do now that negotiations have broken down completely.
British meddling discovered!
Preposterous!

Information has reached $CAPITAL$ from a confidential source that the British jurists in the committee for arbitration of the Venezuela-Guyana border have attempted to make a deal with the American jurists in order to ensure that the committee finds in Britain's favour. While they were, obviously, not successful in this endeavour, neither side is likely to accept any decision the committee finds, so it is effectively dissolved. \n\nOur people are not taking the news lightly, with major demonstrations in $CAPITAL$ taking place, British owned businesses and factories being raided and looted and Anglo-$COUNTRY_ADJ$ relations at an all time low.
British meddling discovered!
Preposterous!

Information has reached $CAPITAL$ from a confidential source that the British jurists in the committee for arbitration of the Venezuela-Guyana border have attempted to make a deal with the American jurists in order to ensure that the committee finds in Britain's favour. While they were, obviously, not successful in this endeavour, neither side is likely to accept any decision the committee finds, so it is effectively dissolved. \n\nOur diplomatic standing has taken a great toll, with many great powers now not willing to take us seriously anymore, and many of our people across the empire sympathise with the Venezuelans. Meanwhile, in Venezuela, British businesses are being thrown out in an eerie echo of the Boston Tea Party, and our influence in South America is sure to suffer.
Our meddling discovered!
Damn!

The arbitration committee for our border with British-occupied Guyana has, to the relief of many, found in our favour, and the British have started evacuating their holdings on the left bank of the Essequibo. Finally, our eastern border is complete!
The Guyana border arbitration
Splendid!

The arbitration committee for our border with British-occupied Guyana has, to the relief of many, found in our favour, however, Britain is now contesting the decision and refuses to leave their holdings in Guyana, despite international scrutiny. Our only hope is that the Americans will continue to support us.
The Guyana border arbitration
Damnation!

The arbitration committee for our border with British-occupied Guyana has, to the interest of many, found in Venezuela's favour, however, Britain is now contesting the decision and refuses to leave their holdings in Guyana, despite international scrutiny. While Britain's image is certainly tarnished by this, the eyes of the world, and especially South America, are now on us. If we want to be taken seriously by countries under our protection, we must condemn this act, perhaps even unto war.
The Guyana border arbitration
We will support our brethren
We cannot stand against Britain

The arbitration committee for our border with British-occupied Guyana has, to the anger of many, found in Britain's favour. We are in no position to contest this decision, and must now leave all of Guyana. The mood was solemn as our diplomats returned to $CAPITAL$ to bear the news, but since the Americans are content with the decision, there is not much we can do but accept the outcome.
The Guyana border arbitration
This is a sad day for $COUNTRY$

Ever since the United States have turned away from $FROMCOUNTRY$ in a crisis, there has been talk in both cabinets and streets of South America straying away from Washington's influence. Now, we have been invited by them to, as a political bloc, boycott the United States of America, and turn to another power for protection, perhaps even one of us.
$FROMCOUNTRY_ADJ$ Winds
We agree, to hell with the Americans!
That is a fool's errand. Washington will protect us.

The Hay–Herrán Treaty was a treaty signed on January 22, 1903, between United States Secretary of State John M. Hay of the United States and Tomás Herrán of Colombia. The treaty offered the United States a renewable lease of 100 years on a six-mile-wide strip across the isthmus of Panama for 10 million dollars and an annual payment of 250,000 dollars, both payments being in gold coin. The $COUNTRY_ADJ$ parliament was furious, however, considering the amount to fall short, considering that the United States was willing to pay 40 million dollars for the New Panama Canal Company and its construction equipment and excavations. Seeing as Herrán was acting without much government or legislative overisght, there is a strong movement to refuse to ratify the treaty until the USA pays a fair amount.
The Hay-Herrán Treaty
We will not accept this occupation until all dues are paid!
We cannot afford to draw the ire of the Americans

The $FROMCOUNTRY_ADJ$ ambassador has issued an appeal for the Hay–Herrán Treaty which outlined our lease of a six-mile-wide strip across the isthmus of Panama for the purposes of attempting to construct a canal there. The ambassador claims that Tomás Herrán, the $FROMCOUNTRY_ADJ$ diplomat who signed the treaty on behalf of $FROMCOUNTRY$ was not acting under proper government and legislative supervision, rendering the treaty illegal under $FROMCOUNTRY_ADJ$ law. They say that in order to prevent a conflict, the $FROMCOUNTRY_ADJ$ senate is prepared to accept the treaty under the same terms, but for a greater payment.
The Hay-Herrán Treaty under scrutiny!
We should do what we can to maintain good relations
It is not our fault they cannot control their own diplomats
Maybe these Panamanian rebels would be more welcoming of American entrepreneurship
If they will not agree to our presence there, we can create a government that will

Our appeal to the Americans that the price Herrán negotiated did not reflect the view of the $COUNTRY_ADJ$ senate on the value of the land being leased has apparently made them reconsider, and they are now offering 40 million dollars. While a few extremists would still like to see more, this is probably all we can hope for.
The Americans pay up!
Splendid!

The Arosemena-Guzmán Treaty, officially called the 'Juris' Treaty on Arbitration between the United States of Colombia and the United States of Venezuela, was an agreement signed in the city of Caracas on September 14, 1881 between the governments of the United States of Colombia and the United States of Venezuela, represented respectively by the plenipotentiary ministers Justo Arosemena and Antonio Guzmán. The objective of this agreement was to clarify the method by which border disputes between the two countries would be resolved. It was agreed that the governments would submit to arbitration by the Spanish monarch, whose award would be final and unappealable. A time was also designated for the parties to present their respective arguments and documentation that supported their corresponding claims.
Arosemena-Guzmán Treaty
Acknowledge the Venezuelan claims
Accept arbitration by the Spanish Monarch
Accept arbitration by the United States of America
We are prepared to defend every inch of $COUNTRY_ADJ$ land

We have been asked to arbitrate a border delineation dispute between Colombia and Venezuela. The border between the two countries was loosely defined in the documents outlining the land granted to the former colonies by the Spanish crown, but these definitions are vague and sometimes in conflict with each other and with the current understanding of the terrain.
The Colombian-Venezuelan Border Arbitration
Favour Colombia
Find a balanced solution
Favour Venezuela

The Arosemena-Guzmán Treaty, officially called the 'Juris' Treaty on Arbitration between the United States of Colombia and the United States of Venezuela, was an agreement signed in the city of Caracas on September 14, 1881 between the governments of the United States of Colombia and the United States of Venezuela, represented respectively by the plenipotentiary ministers Justo Arosemena and Antonio Guzmán. The objective of this agreement was to clarify the method by which border disputes between the two countries would be resolved. For lack of agreement, however, the Colombians walked out and said that they will maintain their claims with force of arms if necessary unless we complied. While submitting sovereign land to such threats would be a blow to our prestige, the disputed regions are small and sparsely populated, so maybe avoiding war will do less harm than standing our ground.
Arosemena-Guzmán Treaty Rejected!
We will not stand for this insolence
This will blow over soon enough
These few strips of contested land aren't worth the diplomatic cost
The Norwegians are not going to lease Bergen to Germany. Should the Germans try to act, we´ll defend Norway.
Norway will not lease Bergen to Germany
Great!

Now that Cuba is under Union authority once more, we must decide what to do with the rebellious rebel island. Some argue the island should be handed over the Afro-Cubano population and granted home rule. Others say military rule will continue to be necessary to keep the peace.
Order restored in Cuba
We must give democracy a chance in Cuba
Cuba must stay under Union rule in order to ensure reconstruction goes smoothly.

With the defeat an inevitability, the Confederate government has fled to the island of Cuba. Some are arguing the Union should make pursuit and invade the island. Others saying it is necessary to take advantage of the peace to end the bloodshed and rebuild the States.
The Confederate Cowards Flee to Cuba!
They shall find no safe havens in Havana!
Let them lick their wounds so that we might heal ours.
